title: Patrick Sercu
text:
Patrick Sercu (27 June 1944 – 19 April 2019) was a Belgian <a href="cycle%20sport">cyclist</a> who was active on the road and track between 1961 and 1983. On track, he won the gold medal in the 1 km time trial at the <a href="1964%20Summer%20Olympics">1964 Summer Olympics</a>, as well as three world titles in the sprint, in 1963, 1967 and 1969. On the road, he earned the <a href="green%20jersey">green jersey</a> in the <a href="1974%20Tour%20de%20France">1974 Tour de France</a>. Sercu is the record holder for the number of <a href="Six-day%20racing">six-day track race</a> victories, having won 88 events out of 223 starts between 1961 and 1983; several of these wins were with cycling great <a href="Eddy%20Merckx">Eddy Merckx</a>. He also won six stages at the <a href="Tour%20de%20France">Tour de France</a> and eleven stages at the <a href="Giro%20d%27Italia">Giro d'Italia</a>.
Biography.
In 1962, aged 18, Sercu won his first national titles, in the sprint and <a href="Madison%20%28cycling%29">madison</a> events. Two years later he was the star attraction at the <a href="Manchester%20Wheelers%27%20Club">Manchester Wheelers' Club</a> Race Meet at the <a href="Fallowfield%20Stadium">Fallowfield track</a> in <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a>.
After retiring from competitions Sercu became organizer of road races and director of the <a href="Six%20Days%20of%20Ghent">Six Days of Ghent</a> and the former <a href="Six%20Days%20of%20Hasselt">Six Days of Hasselt</a>. Sercu died on 19 April 2019, aged 74.
